The Goblin Slayer



Image source: https://goblin-slayer.fandom.com/wiki/Goblin_Slayer


Hi everyone.

This is very much outside my comfort zone but I am always willing to give things a try and do my best!

@Sucy one of our beloved members sent me a PM asking me if I could try to write a Goblin Slayer build for her and her friend who are playing in Arelith.

In Arelith I understand there are a few important differences which include to a level 30 cap, multiclassing requiring at least 3 levels of investment (ie no single 'cheese' levels) and the importance of role-playing which is enforced by DMs. 

There is much much more, which include class specific changes, for example Rangers get 6 skill points / level, uncanny dodge I at 8, evasion at level 9, and hide in plain sight in woodland areas at level 16.



The build draft

This is a build draft that I have worked on with Sucy. I have been told the Goblin Slayer is

- armored
- has high strength and constitution
- very much focused on killing goblins
- although I have noted there is some killing of demons and evil wizards in the Goblin Slayer Wiki page
- is good with traps / stealth
- is good with both melee and ranged attacks

The best way I thought to create these ideas was a Ranger 21 (for favored enemies, bane of enemies, trap setting, stealth, spot/listen etc) with Fighter for weapon/epic weapon specialization and Rogue for disable trap as a class skill, and 3d6 sneak attack. 

I chose to go zen archery with the ranger , making the ranged weapon the secondary attack, and greatsword (sorry I do not know what weapon the goblin slayer uses ! going to need help here) as the main weapon.

Set trap is to modified 11. The ranger can cast one with the land for +4 to set trap, then set deadly traps outside of combat.

With the extra skill points rangers get, this guy can also put points into craft trap (around 25 modified would be nice) for a 50% chance of crafting deadly traps with the right components.

Anyway this is what the draft looks like

I am seeking help with players who have played Arelith to comment as I have not seriously played Arelith at all.

Additionally some comment on RP in relation to the Goblin Slayer himself as I am not familiar with him either

And of course Sucy/friend to comment as well to advise what looks good and what doesn't!

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Arelith offers a Ranger “path” or subclass option called the archer trading in Melee feats (dual wield stuff) for Archer feats and the ability to craft much better ammo (arrows).

http://wiki.arelith.com/Ranger#Archer

Arcane Archer has also has been customised to be an allow Ranger as a qualify class.  If it is feasible that the GoblinSlayer is half elven (I believe he was a human zealot, often human zealots have a skeleton in their closet), then that is an option here.

Alright, not the Goblin Slayer I thought it was.

Arelith also has weapon groups as focus.  In this case I looks like our friend the Goblin Slayer is actually a sword and board character where the “sword” is anything at hand.  So, Weapon master is out as is dual wielding and Arelith Rangers get an AC reward for Dual Wielding that does not quite make up for the loss of a shield.  Taking archer is much more interesting if we stick with Ranger and perhaps a dex/finesse build.  The ranger blade thirst spell has also been modified to add vampiric regen as well as long duration and up to +5 enhancement (essentially the same as GMW for anyone casting it but also the equivalent "+" Vampiric Regen for Ranger making dual wield even more appealing for a Ranger.

Rangers also net additional FE feats (Studied Enemy) and get even more Studied Enemies on a Wisdom mod basis as they increase in levels making a deep ranger build more ideal for anything related to Bane of Enemies.  A 27 Rangers gets 12 enemy feats across 17 enemy groups, if I remember correctly.

The best armour in the game in Arelith is Ranger Armour and meets the old leather with some chain requirements without impacting the Ranger bonuses for wearing light armour.

For a melee build ... hmm if we go Ranger and Bane of enemies, the most powerful builds take advantage of the ranger dual wield and are Ranger/Monk/Bard or Ranger/Monk/Fighter or perhaps even Ranger/Monk/Assassin using Quarterstaff (modified on Arelith for UBAB weapon).  But those are out.

Hmm ... I think for a sword and board w/ armor approach on a Ranger, I would likely go Archer 27 / Specialist 3 Dex build to net the archery path bonuses in lieu of the dual wielding bonus which will not be used.  The archer path is incidental but synergies with the Dex path.

Something like this Archer (27) / Specialist (3) build:
SpoilerRanger(27), Bard(3), Human STR: 16 (18 w/Gift) (26) CON: 16 INT: 14 (16 w/Gift)  01: Ranger(1): Expertise, Improved Expertise, Favored Enemy I, {Rapid Reload, Rapid Shot, Point Blank Shot, Craft Ammunition: Iron}  03: Ranger(3): Weapon Focus 05: Ranger(5): Favored Enemy II, {Studied Enemy I, Craft Ammunition: Steel} 07: Ranger(7): {Woodland Stride} 09: Ranger(9): Improved Critical, {Evasion, Called Shot} 11: Ranger(11) 13: Ranger(13) 15: Ranger(15): Blind Fight, Favored Enemy IV, {Studied Enemy IV} 17: Ranger(17) 19: Ranger(19) 21: Ranger(21): Epic Weapon Focus 23: Ranger(23): Bane of Enemies 25: Ranger(25): Epic Prowess, {Studied Enemy VII} 27: Ranger(27): Great Strength, {Studied Enemy VII} 29: Specialist(2) Skillpoints: 330 BAB: 25 Animal Empathy 33(32), Craft Mastery 30(33), Disable Trap 1(4), Discipline 33(51), Heal 33(35), Hide 33(33), Lore 43(49), Move Silently 33(33), Open Lock 1(1), Search 4(7), Spellcraft 33(36), Spot 33(35), Tumble 30(30) Note: I am not 100% sure of the studied enemies slots, I believe this is accurate but I have not played a Ranger personally and I did not research and adjust the latest wiki change on it.  I am/was an active contributor to the wiki content. - The spell Blade Thirst has been adjusted to 2 turns/level, +5 (at level 26 Ranger), when wielded by a ranger gets Enhancement bonus in Vampiric Regen on every hit, can be cast on ALL melee weapons - A Ranger can and should carry the Crafted Weapon: Elder Dream (spear, one handed on Arelith) for the spell benefits including Nature's Balance w/ Mordakainens Disjunction 1/per day, and Barkskin (12) 3/day, Sleep (2) Unlimited/day  - Under the new system you can select UMD for items (including wands) and/or Lore for Scrolls.  50 Lore nets Level 7 Scrolls including Word of Faith and that is what I built for here as a Ranger you should be able to get divine wands for anything you would want in a wand anyway.  As you can see, your Lore is 49 meaning you will need a single +1 lore on a piece of equipment to net Level 7 Scrolls.
Alternatively, perhaps a COT 15 / PDK 10 / Ro 5 Build both COT and PDK are modified on Arelith making COT useful beyond just saves (although they are exceedingly useful) and PDK a support class that is arguably stronger than bard AND nets guard and ward features for ensuring another persons survival.

Also, it is worth noting that any melee build on Arelith needs Expertise and Improved Expertise, combat is balanced against having it.  There are a few exceptions around classes designed to take hits over avoiding them but those are few.  Even my PM/RDD/Ba has it ...

posts.author: Sucy
posts.content:
Very nice! I'll take a closer look at it after I get home, but as mentioned above, zen archery could probably be dropped in favor of something more melee oriented. Archery would most likely be just as a back up for ranged fights or enemies in unreachable places, but since I'll be playing a mage type in our group, I could also take care of them. On Arelith, weapon specializations / focuses are grouped into categories, so taking "weapon spec/focus: Blades" would cover all bladed weapons such as dagger, short/long swords, katanas, bastard swords etc etc as well. Those are the only changes I could personally give, as building is clearly not my forte!

Edit: Also forgot to mention, upon character creation you can select up to two gifts (Which can give +2 to any stat of your choice) and one minor gift (such as +6 spotting, hide/move silent etc), so you could either keep the two great strength feats and have more over all strength, or drop them for two more feats as your starting str would be 18 with a str gift, and 17 if you chose a con gift as a secondary.

Thanks for commenting Zanithar

I am curious, as I have not written many lvl 30 builds, but in your experience, how do the numbers look regarding Arelith?

For example, for level 40 builds, an base AB (ie with only mundane equipment) of 40+ (Reference: Mithdradates ECB Forum Archives), and a base HP of 400+ (Reference: Kail Pendragon/HipMaestro, ECB Tapatalk Forum) is considered low end for a melee warrior.

Also, if you have some class(es) in mind for this character, let us know.  You would know the character better than we would.  We can take your box and make something mechanically feasible within it I am sure.
From the novels, I think he's considered a ranger/scout fighter hybrid, with some points in rogue due to being able to disable traps and lock pick. Weapon focus/specialization in one handed blades would probably be best, as he normally wields random weapons scavenged off of goblins (so they can't obtain a high end weapon/gear should he fall to them), but normally is just sword+board. There are times he's dual wielded random goblin weaponry or used clubs, but not sure if it'd be worth the feats to take those routes. He doesn't cast magic, but uses scrolls, so high lore and around 15 umd should cover those. I /think/ he's supposed to have darkvision since he delves in goblin caves often, but casting ranger ultravision and RPing it as darkvision should work. Another skill I think would be okay for him to cast is blade thirst since it has vamp regen on Arelith, which would mimic his bloodlust when outnumbered or near death in the novel.

Originally we had planned to go fighter heavy and just take ranger levels for the favored enemy because he's super mundane in the novel, but ranger heavy with fighter levels seems a lot more flexible.

Arelith is VERY AB gated and customised, the acceptable (stat capped and self buffed AB) melee AB would be 47-53. Not including Divine Wrath. Ranged hits a higher mark. Self buffed AC would need to hit 45-55 plus Expertise and Divine Shield as needed for a melee. HP depends on a lot of things but 300 is not unreasonable. A solid barbarian build on Arelith (massively customised class) can clear 1000 HP raging.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Yunim wrote:I don't play on Arelith but I think that most high end items are +3 AB/AC, with some +4 and +5 items that require crafting or farming to get. The rest of the AB comes from buffs, either due to spells or custom changes.
In general the highest weapon enhancement is +3. There are +4 racial and/or class limited and less desirable weapons (clubs, maces) and two +5 weapons: a gnome only crafted light hammer and a loot matrix whip.

The highest full plate armour is +3, but as the base AC drops there is +4, +5 and even two +6 AC armours. A better way of looking at it is with Dex limit, base AC, armour enhancement, the best armour is generally +12 with the above mentioned “Ranger only” armour coming in as the only armour in the game with +13 (Base 3, Enhancement 6, Dex 4). There are solid cloth (Base 0) armour options for Dex based builds that can exceed this of course with capped Dex builds, including another solid Ranger Only armour.

Deflection is limited predominately to helm and +3 is the best outside of enhancement spells: Epic Mage Armour and Armour of Faith.

Natural AC is limited to barkskin potions/wands and is +3. Ranger only Armor and Spear have +4 barkskin on daily use. For anyone other than Druid or Plant Domain Cleric or Ranger the effective Natural AC max is +3. You can use shadow shield scrolls for +5 here as well but they are costly and low duration.

Stats are capped at +12 and with the custom item enchantment process, you can easily cap 2 stats and with some effort cap 3.
Animal spells net a bonus with Greater(+1) and Epic (+2) spell focus Transmutation.

There are many AB class enhancements. Rogues, for example net a +1 Weapon enhancement at 19 and +2 at 24 when wielding rogue proficiency weapons (other than QStaff for monk reasons) that can take their weapon enhancement to +6 with certain racial and class crafted weapons. For the purposes of this calculation all Rogue, Assassin and ShadowDancer levels are added. This is a weapon enhancement and is included in the does it pierce damage reduction calculation.

Fighters get a similar bonus, I believe it falls on level 21 and 28 for Fighter and for any weapon they hold.

Large weapons get a +2 AB (not weapon enhancement stacking) including dual weapons.

PDK gets several feats that increase tohit allowing some PDK builds to hit 53ish AB.

Barbarians get a bunch of hit/damage/AC bonuses depending on how you build them and the various Rage systems are completely changed, much cooler and are under cooldown now.

Many feats have been changed from uses per day to a cool down period including: Divine Wrath, Blinding Speed (this lets a 24 roguish level Rogue/SD/Assassin be hasted for 3 turns with a 4 turn cooldown meaning 75% innate haste on a world with no haste items), Shadow Evade (A 17 ShadowDancer has 100% mechanical uptime on Shadow Evade), etc ...

The baseline exceptional melee with no feat buffs or spell buffs:
BAB: 25
Base Stat: 10 (30 Str/Dex)
Stat Capped: 6
WF: 1
EWF: 2
EP: 1
Weapon Enhancement: 3

Total: 48


Add a small race WM with a scimitar (large weapon for a small race) and you are at 52.

My Travel/War Healer (Cleric subclass) 27 / Monk 3 HOrc QStaff (Monk UBAB) build looks something like this from memory:

BAB: 20
Base Stat: 7
Capped: 6
WF: 1
EWF: 2
Large Weapon: 2
Divine Power: 5
Greater Magic Weapon: 5
Bless: 1
Aid: 1
Prayer: 1
Battletide: 2

Total: 53

HP: 600 (using regen and overheal, a healer thing)
AC: 53 (63 with IE) ish

Capped: Str/Dex/Con/Wis w/ ESF:Transmutation Animal spells and Turns/Level AOV and Regeneration.

Also, all the weapon buff spells do not stack (with few exceptions: Divine Favour, Bless Weapon, BlackStaff, Holy Sword, deafening Clang, Blade Thirst ... but never on attack, just damage). No Darkfire, Flame Weapon or Keen edge on anything other than a mundane weapon with no other enchantments :(

AND HOrc nets Ambidexterity as an added Racial feat making it the two handed weapon racial build frame of choice.

It is a very complex and interesting place to build for ...

posts.author: Zanithar

You can slip in some fighter levels at the cost of dispellable spells (need 27 CL on Arelith), some Favoured and Studied Enemies, the coveted +5 Blade Thirst, none permanent (Henchmen) Animal Empathy and a slightly weaker Bane of Enemies effect which is balanced out by weapon specialisations. 21 is the next natural break point but both fighter and ranger net an extra feat for the remaining 2 levels so likely Ranger is better for dispel resistance. Meaning Ranger(23)/Fighter(4)/Specialist(3) vs Ranger(23)/Fighter(4)/Rogue(3) vs Ranger(27)/Specialist(3).

All are viable builds.

Not to push you one way or another but in the images I saw on the wiki she is a cloth wearing / staff wielding full casting support character. She seems right up the protection healer alley.

If that is what you are looking for, let me know and I’ll drop a build on another thread for it. If you want more of a battle style melee cleric, that is fine as well and I can put one together.

Arelith sadly does not handle high DC caster well meaning it is rough going playing a caster that relies on saves being reasonable and surmountable. However, summons are strong well into the endgame content, so caster tend to be summoners and focus on saveless damage severely limiting offensive spell options.

A protection healer focuses on a defensive casting approach where you summon/buff and heal and is exceedingly good at it. So good in fact that you can kill end game bosses with your buffed summons ... solo.

A battle cleric focuses on magic enhancement to crush your enemies in battle wearing armor/shield and weapon of your choice. You go from weak to strong using a massive amount of magic and given time to cast that magic become a wreaking ball until the magic finishes.
